He then appeared briefly in Suicide Squad before starring in last year's Justice League. context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: What The Original Fast And Furious Director Thinks Of The Franchise Now
context_meta.summary: Few film franchises have shown a willingness to change and evolve with the times quite like the Fast and Furious series. Starting as a spiritual successor to Point Break in 2001, the franchise has grown from a grounded and gritty street-level crime thriller in The Fast and the Furious to a global espionage blockbuster franchise in 2017's The Fate of the Furious. It's a change that has not gone unnoticed by original Fast and Furious director Rob Cohen, and the filmmaker recently opened up in an interview and explained that he's just happy to see original characters remain at the heart of the enhanced spectacle. The franchise went from a Los Angeles story built around a family of multicultural brothers and sisters to what I'll call 'pure spectacle.' The beauty is that the audience has ridden along with it for these 18 years.

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Predicting Marvel's Phase 4 Movies, Knowing Only The Release Dates
context_meta.summary: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 Release Date: 7/31/20 Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 is the only Phase 4 movie that's but talked about in any definitive terms, with James Gunn returning to write and direct the third movie in one of Marvel's top franchises. We know that the movie is aiming for a 2020 release date, but not the specific date. While Guardians is big enough to open in May (which usually has a high-tier Marvel movie), opening in July isn't a bad spot. Seeing as how Vol. 3 is likely further along in the development process than other projects, it'll hit theaters sooner rather than later. Honestly, I feel like Marvel is hiding a release date for May 2020, which would be an ideal spot

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: One Cool Jumanji: Welcome To The Jungle Stunt Wasn't Actually CGI
context_meta.summary: Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle took much of its inspiration from video games, which meant a lot of what we saw had to be created digitally. However, one remarkable stunt was actually entirely real. The movie follows our four heroes as they attempt to replace a magic jewel atop a massive mountain shaped like a cat. Dwayne Johnson ends up driving a motorcycle off the mountain, before he jumps off the motorcycle and flips his way on to the top of the statue. According to a new bonus feature for the movie, somebody actually did exactly that without the help of CGI.

context_meta.title: Disney Responds To Han Solo Movie Poster Plagiarism Claim
context_meta.summary: This probably isn't the type of press that Disney was hoping Solo: A Star Wars Story would be getting less than three months before its release. The studio is being accused of plagiarizing a French artist with its posters for the Han Solo standalone movie. Hachim Bahous, the artist behind a series of album covers released by Sony Music in France, claims that the Solo posters made liberal use of his own work in a post on Facebook that has since been taken down. "I am flattered that the quality of my work is recognized, but it is still pure and simple forgery, I have not been asked for my permission, I wish to be credited and paid for this work I have done for Sony," he wrote in the post. context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: What it's like to be a first-time nominee at the Oscars
context_meta.summary: It's been five weeks of firsts for documentary filmmaker Laura Checkoway. Since receiving her first Oscar nomination on Jan. 23 for her documentary short "Edith+Eddie," Checkoway has dined at her first Oscars luncheon, shopped for her first Oscars dress and attended her first Oscars ceremony. "I've never used the word 'incredible' so many times in my life," the journalist-turned-filmmaker told ABC News, adding that "the Academy Awards was not in my field of vision" when she started making the film about elder abuse and America's oldest interracial couple.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Oscar Telecast Viewership Down 16%
context_meta.summary: All the glitz and glamour of the 90th annual Academy Awards was not enough to overcome a cool reception from U.S. audiences. Variety reported Monday morning that the Nielsen overnight ratings for the scheduled three-hour prime-time broadcast that ran to almost four hours dropped 16% year over year. The data are not adjusted to account for the 5:00 p.m. start time for the show on the West Coast, well outside the prime time window. The overnight ratings also do not include the 48 minutes the program ran over its time slot in the Eastern time zone. Those were the minutes when the top awards for acting and movie were announced. According to Variety, the 8:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. portion of the broadcast

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Kimmel leads Oscar celebration of gender equality, artistic diversity
context_meta.summary: (This story has been refiled to fix typographical error in 3rd paragraph to make it "preyed" instead of "prayed") By Steve Gorman LOS ANGELES (Reuters) - Oscar host Jimmy Kimmel on Sunday led a star-studded tribute to Hollywood's best in honoring the campaign against sexual misconduct and breakthroughs in racial and ethnic diversity beginning to transform the movie business. The live telecast, which ran for nearly four hours, built on the socially conscious thrust that has marked Oscar night during the past few years, transforming the 90th edition of the glittering awards show into a conversation about sexual politics and inclusion. In his opening monologue, Kimmel skewered the class of powerful men who preyed on women with a sight gag focused on a larger-than-life Oscar statue on stage, noting the male sculpture's anatomically simplified lack of genitalia.

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Meet Maisie Sly, the profoundly deaf girl from Swindon who brought sign language to the Oscars
context_meta.summary: This year’s Oscars were a subdued affair after months of depressing news from sexual harassment in the entertainment industry. Hollywood, and its onlookers, was certainly in need of a wholesome good news story. But one star cut through the gloom: six-year-old Maisie Sly, a deaf girl from Swindon who was behind the ceremony’s most touching moment. Rachel Shenton, writer and actress of 2017 film The Silent Child, signed her acceptance speech for Best Live Action Short Film Oscar so that Sly could understand it. “Our movie is about a deaf child being born into a world of silence,” Shenton explained, with shaking hands. It's not exaggerated or sensationalised, this is happening: millions of children all over the world live in silence and face communication barriers, particularly in access to education." Hours earlier, Sly dazzled as the littlest person on the red carpet in a smart midnight blue dress, a matching bow across her blonde hair, arriving at the 90th Academy Awards hand-in-hand with Shenton and her fiance, Chris Overton, who directed the film. Sly was five when she played Libby, a four-year-old who was born into a hearing family. Libby’s parents and siblings are a normal family, but unwittingly shut out their deaf daughter, who spent her early years in confounding silence. After remaining undiagnosed for three-and-a-half years, audiences watch as an angry and introverted Libby is coaxed out of herself after a social worker, Joanne (played by Shenton) is brought in to teach her British Sign Language. Fortunately, Sly’s own story differs greatly: both her parents are deaf, as is her older brother Jack, eight, and little sister Chloe. Like her siblings, Sly learned BSL from infancy. But for her father, Gibson, Libby’s experiences are all too relatable. He was also born to a hearing family and wasn’t diagnosed until he was three. He later attended a mainstream primary school. “I was lonely, frustrated and rebellious,” he told the Swindon Advertiser last year. “It wasn’t until I met Elizabeth and learned BSL that I found my deaf identity.” As Shenton said, the problem of deaf integration is widespread. Every week 34 babies are born deaf in the UK, and 90 per cent of them have hearing parents. “The Silent Child shines a light on the challenges and injustices that too many deaf children experience as part of their daily lives,” Susan Daniels, Chief Executive of the National Deaf Children's Society, told The Telegraph. The whole Sly family accompanied the six-year-old to Los Angeles for Sunday night’s ceremony. It is her second trip to America in the past 12 months, after Sly made her maiden voyage over the Atlantic to see the film premiere at the Rhode Island International Film Festival during her summer holidays. Sly won Best Actress at the festival, which made The Silent Child eligible to enter the Oscars. The film’s Facebook page shows how the family have been enjoying Los Angeles’ landmarks over the past two weeks, with trips to Universal Studios, the Los Angeles Zoo and a stroll down Hollywood Walk of Fame. Sly and Shenton in The Silent Child It’s all a rapid change for the “bubbly” schoolgirl, who attends Red Oaks Primary School – which is a mainstream school with a special resource provision for deaf children – near her home of Upper Stratton. “She’s a lovely girl,” said headteacher Rachel Surch. “She’s a real character, with lots of personality and lots of friends. Just like our other deaf children, she fits right in with her mainstream friends - being deaf doesn’t hold her back, nor should it.” Red Oaks celebrated The Silent Child by hosting a red carpet premiere for its pupils in the school hall. Speaking the morning after the film’s Oscar win, Surch said it had “been a bit of a whirlwind”. Sly was part of a nationwide casting search for The Silent Child, and auditioned after her parents saw an advert on Facebook looking for a four- or five-year-old girl who was profoundly deaf and used sign language. Shenton said that 100 children auditioned, but she and the production team knew Sly was their star instantly. "Maisie walked in and we all say, all our production team, that we made our decision within 10 seconds, she was just perfect," she told Good Morning Britain. The Oscar-winner fell in love with British Sign Language during her teens, after her father lost his hearing as a result of undergoing chemotherapy. He spent the last two years of his life deaf, and died when Shenton was 14. She was driven to juggle her nascent acting career – which included roles in TV dramas such as Holby City and Waterloo Road – with volunteering as a BSL interpreter and working with a local charity for deaf people. The stories of people she met inspired her to write The Silent Child, especially those of middle-class families who were left dumbfounded upon having a deaf child. Sly has now joined the ranks of Marlee Matlin, who became the first deaf actress – and the youngest women ever – to win Best Actress at the 1986 Oscars for Children of a Lesser God. “She is a confident, happy little girl and maybe she could be the next Matlin,” Gibson said last May. “But we do know that acting opportunity for a deaf girl are few and far between.” The Silent Child writer and star Rachel Shenton, actress Maisie Sly and director Chris Overton Credit:  CARLO ALLEGRI The lack of deaf actors on screen was another major motivation for Shenton to make The Silent Child: “I’ve seen numerous projects where hearing people are cast to play deaf roles,” she said on Good Morning Britain. The problem has frequently found the silver screen, such as when Tammy Blanchard played the wife of Matt Damon’s character in The Good Shepherd (2006), or James Stewart’s role as the deaf George Bailey in It’s A Wonderful Life. But change could be on the horizon. October will see the release of Wonderstruck, Todd Haynes’ adaptation of Brian Selznick’s time-travelling coming of age novel, which sees 14-year-old deaf actress Millie Simmonds take a major part. After Sly’s success, who knows which other deaf children may be inspired to follow her lead. As Daniels says: “For deaf children across the globe, this film, its story, and its talented leading lady all show there is no limit to what deaf children can achieve.”

context_meta.title: NASCAR's Richard Petty is auctioning off cars and memorabilia from his racing career
context_meta.summary: (FOX NEWS) - “The King” is cleaning out his closet. Living racing legend Richard Petty is auctioning off a trove of trophies, memorabilia and even some of the cars from his 60-year NASCAR career. They include a 1974 Dodge Charger that he won 31 races with, including the 1974 Daytona 500. The event is being organized by Julien's Auctions and will take place at the Planet Hollywood Resort & Casino in Las Vegas on May 12. "You name it, we've got a little bit of everything. Some of the uniforms, some stuff that really meant something in my career," Petty told the Associated Press. Petty said he has more cars and memorabilia than he can showcase in his museum in Level Cross, North Carolina. "We feel

context_meta.title: 'Coco' Director Throws Shade At Trump's 'Unacceptable' Remarks On Mexicans
context_meta.summary: The team behind “Coco,” this year’s Academy Award winner for best animated feature, used their acceptance speech as an opportunity to stand up for Mexico and Mexicans in the face of xenophobia. Since then, Trump has made a number of demeaning comments about Mexico and Mexican-Americans in the past, including calling immigrants rapists. The president also claimed that Judge Gonzalo Curiel― an American born to Mexican immigrant parents― wouldn’t able to rule fairly in a case involving his controversial border wall (Curiel actually sided with Trump.) Remarks like these gave the film a new urgency, Unkrich said.

Since the main character is described as having grown up "racing on the rural roads of the Midwest," Polaris' off-road vehicles like its RZR side-by-side would certainly fit. And

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Gary Oldman says playing Winston Churchill was ‘a wonderful ride’ as he gathers with nominees for Oscars
context_meta.summary: Gary Oldman said playing Winston Churchill had been “a wonderful ride”,  on the eve of the Academy Awards ceremony that could see him take home his first Oscar. The British actor is hotly tipped to be named best actor for his role in The Darkest Hour, which depicts the early days of Churchill’s rule as the Nazis swept across Europe and threatened the United Kingdom. Yet, speaking to The Telegraph at an event to celebrate British film, Oldman, 59, was philosophical about his chances. “Sunday will be, what Sunday will be,” he said, with a wry smile. Ladbrokes make Oldman the favourite at 1/25, with fellow Briton Daniel Kaluuya, nominated for Get Out, at 16 to one – equal with Timothee Chalamet for Call Me By Your Name. Daniel Day-Lewis, already the most successful lead actor in Oscars history, with three best actor awards, is 25 to one for his swansong, Phantom Thread. Denzel Washington is considered the outsider for Roman J. Israel Esq, with Ladbrokes rating him a 100 to one shot.       If Oldman wins, he will be the first Briton named best actor since Eddie Redmayne, who won three years ago for his portrayal of Stephen Hawking in The Theory of Everything. Defeating Day-Lewis - a fellow Londoner who rose through the British theatre scene alongside Oldman - would be the crowning moment in a dazzlingly diverse 35-year career. “Churchill has been such fabulous company,” Oldman said, sipping his coffee. The actor has been teetotal since a well-publicised battle with alcohol in the 1990s. Oscars 2018 Full list of nominees “I’m so glad there has been such support for it, and interest in it. And that the Churchill family has embraced it.” Randolph Churchill, the great-great grandson of the prime minister, heaped praise on Oldman, as well as Kristin Scott Thomas, as Churchill’s wife, and Ben Mendelsohn, who plays King George VI. “We’re always a little bit nervous about these ventures,” he said last month. “But I can say wholeheartedly, Gary, Kristin Scott Thomas, Ben have absolutely done us so proud.”  The film is up for six awards, including best picture. Dunkirk, its fellow Second World War tale, is nominated for eight. “It’s very simple,” Mr Churchill said. “Gary absolutely nailed it.”
